name: 2-chloro-3,6-difluorophenol
Reason: 2-chloro-3,6-difluorophenol has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components. Starting with the basic unit of phenol, which has a melting point of 5.5°C, we have substantial structural components to consider. The chlorine atom introduces a significant dipole moment, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +5°C. The fluorine atoms, being highly polarizable, also contribute to the melting point due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10°C each. The fused aromatic ring system enhances the melting point due to increased molecular rigidity and pi-stacking interactions; this effect is estimated to add about +25°C for each additional fused ring.
